Historically and culturally among the most important nations in the Western world, France has also played a highly significant role in international affairs, with former colonies in every corner of the globe. Bounded by the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Atlantic-Ocean" class="md-crosslink">Atlantic Ocean</a> and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Mediterranean-Sea" class="md-crosslink">Mediterranean Sea</a>, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Alps" class="md-crosslink">Alps</a> and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Pyrenees" class="md-crosslink">Pyrenees</a>, France has long provided a geographic, economic, and linguistic bridge joining northern and southern Europe. It is Europe’s most important agricultural producer and one of the world’s leading industrial powers.</p><!--[P1]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="61202"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/83/683-004-DD436A53.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/83/683-004-DD436A53.jpg" alt="France. Political map: boundaries, cities. Includes locator." data-width="525" data-height="435"></div></div><figcaption><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="1642"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/87/687-004-76F4171F.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/87/687-004-76F4171F.jpg" alt="The château of Villandry, built in 1532, and its formal gardens in the Loire valley just east of Tours, France." data-width="306" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The château of Villandry, built in 1532, and its formal gardens in the Loire valley just east of Tours, France.</span><cite>© Rob Palmer from TSW—CLICK/Chicago</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML1]--><p>France is among the globe’s oldest nations, the product of an alliance of duchies and principalities under a single ruler in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Middle-Ages" class="md-crosslink">Middle Ages</a>. Today, as in that era, central <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/authority" class="md-crosslink autoxref">authority</a> is vested in the state, even though a measure of <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/autonomy" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="autonomy">autonomy</a> has been granted to the country’s <em>régions</em> in recent decades. The French people look to the state as the primary guardian of liberty, and the state in turn provides a generous program of amenities for its citizens, from free education to health care and pension plans. Even so, this centralist tendency is often at odds with another long-standing theme of the French nation: the insistence on the supremacy of the individual. On this matter historian <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jules-Michelet" class="md-crosslink">Jules Michelet</a> remarked, “<a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/England" class="md-crosslink">England</a> is an empire, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Germany" class="md-crosslink">Germany</a> is a nation, a race, France is a person.” Statesman <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Charles-de-Gaulle-president-of-France" class="md-crosslink">Charles de Gaulle</a>, too, famously complained, “Only peril can bring the French together. One can’t impose unity out of the blue on a country that has 265 kinds of cheese.”</p><!--[P2]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="208497"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/42/183642-004-61954847.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/42/183642-004-61954847.jpg" alt="France" data-width="480" data-height="460"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">France</strong><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML2]--><p>This tendency toward <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/individualism" class="md-crosslink autoxref">individualism</a> joins with a pluralist outlook and a great interest in the larger world. Even though its imperialist stage was driven by the impulse to civilize that world according to French standards (<em>la mission civilisatrice</em>), the French still note approvingly the words of writer <span id="ref1029874"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Gustave-Flaubert" class="md-crosslink">Gustave Flaubert</a>:</p><!--[P3]--><blockquote><p>I am no more modern than I am ancient, no more French than Chinese; and the idea of <em>la patrie</em>, the fatherland—that is, the obligation to live on a bit of earth coloured red or blue on a map, and to detest the other bits coloured green or black—has always seemed to me narrow, restricted, and ferociously stupid.</p></blockquote><p>At once universal and particular, French <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/culture" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="culture">culture</a> has spread far and greatly influenced the development of art and science, particularly anthropology, philosophy, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/sociology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">sociology</a>.</p><!--[P5]--><p>France has also been influential in government and civil affairs, giving the world important democratic ideals in the age of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Enlightenment-European-history" class="md-crosslink">Enlightenment</a> and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/French-Revolution" class="md-crosslink">French Revolution</a> and inspiring the growth of reformist and even revolutionary movements for generations. The present <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Fifth-Republic-French-history" class="md-crosslink">Fifth Republic</a> has, however, enjoyed notable stability since its promulgation on September 28, 1958, marked by a tremendous growth in private <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/initiative" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="initiative">initiative</a> and the rise of centrist politics. Although France has engaged in long-running disputes with other European powers (and, from time to time, with the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/United-States" class="md-crosslink">United States</a>, its longtime ally), it emerged as a leading member in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/European-Union" class="md-crosslink">European Union (EU)</a> and its predecessors. From 1966 to 1995 France did not participate in the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/integrated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="integrated">integrated</a> military structure of the <span id="ref1029873"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/North-Atlantic-Treaty-Organization" class="md-crosslink">North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)</a>, retaining full control over its own air, ground, and naval forces; beginning in 1995, however, France was represented on the NATO Military Committee, and in 2009 French President <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Nicolas-Sarkozy" class="md-crosslink">Nicolas Sarkozy</a> announced that the country would rejoin the organization’s military command. As one of the five permanent members of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/United-Nations-Security-Council" class="md-crosslink">United Nations Security Council</a>—together with the United States, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Russia" class="md-crosslink">Russia</a>, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/United-Kingdom" class="md-crosslink">United Kingdom</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/China" class="md-crosslink">China</a>—France has the right to veto decisions put to the council.</p><!--[P6]--><p>The capital and by far the most important city of France is <span id="ref468796"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Paris" class="md-crosslink">Paris</a>, one of the world’s preeminent cultural and commercial centres. A majestic city known as the <em>ville lumière</em>, or “city of light,” Paris has often been remade, most famously in the mid-19th century under the command of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Georges-Eugene-Baron-Haussmann" class="md-crosslink">Georges-Eugène, Baron Haussman</a>, who was committed to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Napoleon-III-emperor-of-France" class="md-crosslink">Napoleon III</a>’s vision of a modern city free of the choleric swamps and congested alleys of old, with broad avenues and a regular plan. Paris is now a sprawling metropolis, one of Europe’s largest conurbations, but its historic heart can still be <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/traversed" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="traversed">traversed</a> in an evening’s walk. Confident that their city stood at the very centre of the world, Parisians were once given to referring to their country as having two parts, Paris and <em>le désert</em>, the wasteland beyond it. Metropolitan Paris has now extended far beyond its ancient suburbs into the countryside, however, and nearly every French town and village now numbers a retiree or two driven from the city by the high <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/cost-of-living" class="md-crosslink autoxref">cost of living</a>, so that, in a sense, Paris has come to embrace the desert and the desert Paris.</p><!--[P7]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="100157"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/68/94468-004-1D664C73.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/68/94468-004-1D664C73.jpg" alt="Paris skyline at dusk." data-width="550" data-height="363"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Paris skyline at dusk.</span><cite>© Digital Vision/Getty Images</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML7]--><p>Among France’s other major cities are <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Lyon-France" class="md-crosslink">Lyon</a>, located along an ancient Rhône valley trade route linking the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/North-Sea" class="md-crosslink">North Sea</a> and the Mediterranean; <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Marseille" class="md-crosslink">Marseille</a>, a multiethnic port on the Mediterranean founded as an entrepôt for Greek and Carthaginian traders in the 6th century <span class="text-smallcaps">bce</span>; <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Nantes" class="md-crosslink">Nantes</a>, an industrial centre and deepwater harbour along the Atlantic coast; and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Bordeaux" class="md-crosslink">Bordeaux</a>, located in southwestern France along the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Garonne-River" class="md-crosslink">Garonne River</a>.</p><!--[P8]--></section><nav class="prev-next-pagination margin-top-50 margin-bottom-50 grid no-gutter  has-next">        <div class="pagination-control
